summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 between an FBI forensic examiner and a federal prosecutor discussing the processing of digital evidence (image and video files) from devices seized in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The examiner provides updates on the status of several Mac computers, notes one drive was wiped, and discusses scheduling for further review.

persons.name: M, I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner communicating with prosecutors about the status of processing digital evidence from Epstein devices, providing technical updates and availability for calls.

persons.name: M, (USANYS)
persons.context: Federal prosecutor from the Southern District of New York requesting updates and coordinating the review of image and video files extracted from Epstein devices.

connections.description: Working together on the forensic examination and legal review of digital evidence in the Epstein case, as shown by their email coordination about device processing and scheduling calls.

events.title: Forensic Update on Epstein Devices
events.description: FBI forensic examiner informs prosecutor that processing of Epstein device images/videos is going slowly, hopes to have 2 more machines ready by Wednesday and the remainder by the end of the following week.

events.title: Coordination Call Scheduled
events.description: Prosecutor and FBI examiner schedule a call for 1:30 PM to discuss the most efficient way to review the Epstein image and video files.

events.title: Delivery of Initial Evidence
events.description: FBI examiner had dropped off image and video files from Epstein devices to the prosecutor's office earlier in the day.

keyFacts: FBI forensic examiners were actively processing image and video files from multiple Mac computers (e.g., NYCO24328, NYCO24329, NYCO24353) seized in the Epstein investigation as of October 2020.
One device, NYCO24342, was identified as a wiped drive with no data recoverable.
The email chain shows ongoing coordination between law enforcement (FBI CART) and federal prosecutors to manage and review a large volume of digital evidence.
The correspondence is explicitly marked as 'SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER' regarding specific paragraphs, indicating sensitive or restricted information.
